results.abstract: Former Microsoft engineer Charles Simonyi is scheduled to depart on 12-day orbital flight to International Space Station on Soyuz TMA spacecraft; Simonyi will be fifth civilian space tourist to pay about $25 million to Space Adventures to do so; photo (S)

headline.main: Former Microsoft Engineer Prepares to Blast Off

results.snippet: This week, the former Microsoft engineer who oversaw the creation of the “Word” and “Excel” software programs is scheduled to depart on an orbital flight to the International Space Station.
results.lead_paragraph: At 13, Charles Simonyi won a Junior Astronaut competition in Hungary that earned him a trip to Moscow to meet one of the first cosmonauts. This week, on Saturday, the former Microsoft engineer who oversaw the creation of the ''Word'' and ''Excel'' software programs is scheduled to depart on a roughly 12-day orbital flight to the International Space Station on a Soyuz TMA spacecraft, along with two cosmonauts. Having paid about $25 million to Space Adventures, a privately owned space tourism company, Mr. Simonyi will become the fifth civilian space tourist to pay for the out-of-this-world experience. Mr. Simonyi will not only orbit the earth at approximately 17,500 kilometers per hour, he will also assist in space station research and share a six-course meal -- prepared by the French chef Alain Ducasse from a menu chosen by Martha Stewart -- with the crew. Mr. Simonyi's Web site and blog (www.charlesinspace.com) is already loaded with images (including a hilarious video of him doing weightless exercises in the zero G simulator), and has a ''Kid's Space,'' with a link where children can pose questions about space travel.

results.abstract: Florida University athletic director Jeremy Foley prepares for men's basketball team's NCAA tournament final against Ohio State University; photo (M)

headline.main: Bumpy Ride to the Top for an Athletic Director

results.snippet: With a championship team in football and a contender for the men’s basketball title, the Gators’ athletic director is enjoying his success.

byline.original: By JOE LAPOINTE; Pete Thamel contributed reporting

results.lead_paragraph: During the N.C.A.A. championship game between Ohio State and Florida on Monday night at the Georgia Dome, Gators Athletic Director Jeremy Foley said that he would touch his good-luck charm frequently. It was given to him two years ago by a friend in Columbus, Ohio; it is a nut that fell from a Buckeye tree (aesculus glabra), the state tree of Ohio. Foley said Sunday that it did not bother him that his totem of happy fortune represented the nickname of the opposing team.

results.abstract: Orange County, Fla, Judge Marc L Lubet says he will seal any psychological evaluations of Capt Lisa M Nowak, former astronaut accused of trying to kidnap romantic rival (M)

headline.main: Judge to Seal Psychological Files in Trial of Former Astronaut

results.snippet: The judge also warned that continuing communication by lawyers with the news media “will keep this case stoked up in the press.”
results.lead_paragraph: A judge said Thursday that he would seal any psychological evaluations of Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the former astronaut accused of trying to kidnap a romantic rival. He also ordered lawyers in the case not to issue press releases, and he scheduled a hearing for Monday to determine whether additional documents should be sealed.

results.abstract: Judge Marc L Lubet cancels scheduling hearing on his plan to seal court documents in case of Capt Lisa M Nowak, former astronaut accused of attacking romantic rival, Capt Colleen Shipman, and says he will allow release of records, with exception of psychological evaluations (M)

headline.main: Judge Reverses Stand in Case of Ex-Astronaut

results.snippet: A judge canceled a hearing on his plan to seal court documents in the case of a former astronaut accused of attacking a romantic rival and said he would allow the release of the records.
results.lead_paragraph: Just hours after scheduling a hearing on his plan to seal court documents in the case of a former astronaut accused of attacking a romantic rival, a judge canceled the hearing and said he would allow the release of the records, with the exception of psychological evaluations. The judge, Marc L. Lubet of Orange County Circuit Court, released a written order Thursday evening reversing his earlier decision to seal the records in the case of the former astronaut, Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, pending the hearing he had scheduled for Tuesday.

results.abstract: Charles Simonyi, software pioneer, has paid estimated $20 million to visit International Space Station in Soyuz spacecraft; photo (M)

headline.main: On the Launching Pad: A $20 Million Childhood Dream

results.snippet: Charles Simonyi, a software pioneer who led the teams that gave the world Microsoft Word and Excel, is the fifth so-called space tourist.
results.lead_paragraph: At 17, Charles Simonyi slipped out of Soviet-controlled Hungary to seek freedom. At 33, he slipped away from the safety of a large corporation, Xerox, in search of fortune at a young start-up named Microsoft. And today, at 58, that fortune is allowing him to slip the surly bonds of Earth, at least for a couple of weeks, to visit the International Space Station.

results.abstract: Lisa Ristow and Mark Polansky, who were featured in Vows column when they were married in 2001, discuss their marriage and family; photos (M)
results.snippet: A follow-up on a couple featured in Vows on Oct. 14, 2001.
results.lead_paragraph: FOR most of his life, Mark L. Polansky's heart was in outer space. Then one day, he agreed to give Lisa N. Ristow, a striking blonde and former high-school cheerleader, a ride to a work-related brunch. She appeared at his doorstep in Houston, and his heart came screeching back to planet Earth. Mr. Polansky, 50, an astronaut who piloted his first mission on the shuttle Atlantis in 2001, and Mrs. Polansky, 36, who worked for a NASA contractor in Houston, married a few months after Mr. Polansky arrived home from the Atlantis mission. Since then, they have traversed the Earth inside the atmosphere, to Italy, France and just recently, to the vineyards of the Napa Valley.

results.abstract: Atlantic Monthly Press will release book The Diary of Peter Ginz: 1941-1942 to coincide with Holocaust Rememberance Day; book adds another adolescent voice to literature of Holocaust; while The Diary of Anne Frank is full of flowery prose of hope and dreams, Ginz's diary offers unsentimental perspective on his changing world; photos (M)

headline.main: A Youthful Chronicle Of Wartime In Prague

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND MINORITIES

results.snippet: The forthcoming publication of “The Diary of Petr Ginz: 1941-1942” adds another adolescent voice to the literature of the Holocaust.
results.lead_paragraph: The first sign that things aren't quite right comes when Jews are required to wear a badge, a black and yellow star of David, on the outside of their clothes. And yet 13-year-old Petr Ginz remains wryly amused, writing in his diary: ''When I went to school, I counted sixty-nine 'sheriffs.' '' Such is the life of a young Czechoslovakian Jewish boy living in Prague in 1941, and it is a life that Petr meticulously documented in his diary until he was sent on a transport to Theresienstadt and, ultimately, to his death in an Auschwitz gas chamber two years later. On Sunday, to coincide with Holocaust Remembrance Day, Atlantic Monthly Press will officially release Petr's story, ''The Diary of Petr Ginz: 1941-1942.'' The book is already available in stores and online.

results.abstract: Article on standup surf paddling, in which surfers use oversize distance paddling boards; photos (M)

headline.main: Whatever Size the Wave, Some Surfers Reach for the Paddle

results.snippet: Standup paddling, with a big oar and on a huge board, can put you way out with the big waves.
results.lead_paragraph: THE high cliffs and green hills of La Jolla, Calif., are undeniably gorgeous, but the show going on in the water below them was positively dizzying. Golden Garibaldi fish swam among swaying leaves of kelp; stingrays and a small shark kicked up grainy clouds of sand. A dark reef loomed amid imposing waves as we approached the headland. I was experiencing my first successful attempt at standup paddling on a surfboard, and the sensation of rowing upright across the glassy ocean without the energy of a swell made me feel like an astronaut on a spacewalk. Standing above the aquatic world like this turned surfing into an utterly new experience.

results.abstract: Deena Kastor finishes fifth at Boston Marathon after suffering from stomach pains; photo (M)

headline.main: Stomach Pain Slows One of the Favorites

results.snippet: In a race slowed by unkind weather, Deena Kastor ran the slowest of her nine career marathons.
results.lead_paragraph: Deena Kastor had one race plan for fairly decent weather and one for the stinging wind and rain that affected the Boston Marathon on Monday. She did not plan for stomach cramps halfway through the race, which reduced Kastor, a favorite, into a fifth-place finisher. A 34-year-old Californian, Kastor was making her Boston debut a year after setting the American record, 2 hours 19 minutes 36 seconds, in London.

results.snippet: Even though it's still April, the May sweeps period has begun, and this week ABC offers one of the month's most special episodes: the two-hour ''GREY'S ANATOMY'' that will serve as Kate Walsh's audition for her (that is, Dr. Addison Montgomery's)...
results.lead_paragraph: Even though it's still April, the May sweeps period has begun, and this week ABC offers one of the month's most special episodes: the two-hour ''GREY'S ANATOMY'' that will serve as Kate Walsh's audition for her (that is, Dr. Addison Montgomery's) own series (Thursday, 9 p.m.). Auditioning along with her will be guest stars like Taye Diggs, Tim Daly and Amy Brenneman, who will reportedly pop up when Ms. Walsh's character makes a trip to California to visit old school friends. Some other May sweepings: In an episode titled ''Rocket Man'' (NBC, Tuesday, 9 p.m.), ''LAW & ORDER: CRIMINAL INTENT'' rips from the headlines the sad case, barely four months old, of the astronaut Lisa Marie Nowak. In this telling the possible romantic rival has been murdered, and the space-shuttle-piloting object of everyone's affections is played by Tate Donovan. And My Network TV, still trying to find its way after abandoning one of television's most short-lived programming strategies (telenovelas? in English?), presents ''BODY DOUBLES: INTERNATIONAL TWINS SEARCH'' (Tuesday, 9 p.m.), billed as a ''most beautiful twins'' competition. Last week in this slot, My Network TV gave us ''Ujena Bikini Jam.'' Such, apparently, is the value of prime-time broadcast real estate these days. At the higher end of the culture scale, Turner Classic Movies presents a new two-part documentary, ''BRANDO'' (Tuesday and Wednesday, 8 p.m.). Talking heads, including Martin Scorsese, Al Pacino and Edward Norton, share their memories of watching and working with the great actor (Mr. Scorsese: ''Every day cinema was being reinvented.''). TCM will also be showing eight Brando films over those two nights, including ''THE WILD ONE'' (Wednesday, 9:30 p.m.) and ''ON THE WATERFRONT'' (Thursday, 12:30 a.m.). On PBS, ''American Masters'' has a two-hour profile of the pop-music impresario Ahmet Ertegun, who died in December. ''ATLANTIC RECORDS: THE HOUSE THAT AHMET BUILT'' (Wednesday night on most PBS stations; check local listings) includes interviews with Mr. Ertegun covering a four-year period. And ''American Experience'' and ''Frontline'' have combined to produce ''THE MORMONS'' (Monday and Tuesday nights on most PBS stations), a four-hour examination of the Mormon Church's history and influence.

results.abstract: Film Disturbia is No 1 at box office for third weekend in row with $9.1 million in ticket sales; photo (S)
results.snippet: “Disturbia” fends off new challengers at the movie box office, Prince Charles will skip a memorial concert for Diana, Princess of Wales and more culture news.
results.lead_paragraph: 'Disturbia' Fends Off New Challengers The spring peeper movie ''Disturbia'' (distributed by Paramount and starring Shia LaBeouf, above, spent a third weekend atop the North American box-office rankings, taking in $9.1 million, according to estimates compiled by the tracking company Media by Numbers. But two newcomers crashed the top five. ''The Invisible'' (Buena Vista), an excursion into fright, finished second with $7.6 million, and ''Next'' (Paramount), starring Nicolas Cage as a Las Vegas magician who can see into the future, was third with a gross of $7.2 million. Not far behind, with $7 million in its second week, was the thriller ''Fracture'' (New Line). The ice-skating comedy ''Blades of Glory'' (Paramount) was next with $5.2 million in its fifth week in theaters, bringing its total to $108 million. Prince Charles to Skip Diana Memorial Concert Prince Charles and his wife, Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, will not attend the concert planned for July 1 by his sons, Princes William and Harry (right, with William on the left), to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the death of their mother and Charles's former wife, Diana, Princess of Wales, Agence France-Presse reported. Among the scheduled performers at the new 90,000-seat Wembley Stadium in London are Elton John, Rod Stewart, Kanye West and Duran Duran. ''The concert is really for the younger generation to enjoy,'' The Times of London quoted Prince Charles's spokesman as saying. ''There will be a memorial service for Diana on Aug. 31, which will be an event for all generations of the Windsors to come together.'' Charles and Diana were married in 1981, separated in 1992 and divorced in 1996. She died in a car crash in Paris in 1997. Jazz Festival Gets Support The New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival has attracted its first long-term corporate sponsor, The Associated Press reported. Organizers said the sponsorship of Shell Exploration and Production, an energy development company, would keep the event from being scaled back as New Orleans recovers from the devastation of Hurricane Katrina. ''It changes a lot of things,'' Quint Davis, the producer and director of the festival, said. ''We're able to make long-term plans for the festival now.'' Frank Glaviano, a Shell vice president for production, said, ''We wanted to give a gift to the people of New Orleans after all they had gone through.'' The sponsorship will continue through at least 2010. This year's festival began on Friday and resumes next Friday. 'Frankenstein' in Seattle ''Young Frankenstein,'' the latest musical to be adapted from a Mel Brooks film comedy, will hold its pre-Broadway tryout in Seattle from Aug. 4 through Sept. 1 at the Paramount Theater, Variety.com reported. The recently closed Broadway hit ''The Producers,'' also adapted from a film by Mr. Brooks, had its tryout in Chicago. Other Broadway shows that had pre-Broadway runs in Seattle include ''Hairspray'' and ''The Wedding Singer.'' ''Young Frankenstein,'' planned for Broadway in the fall, reunites Mr. Brooks with Thomas Meehan, with whom he wrote the book for ''The Producers,'' and with Susan Stroman, the hit's choreographer and director. Casting and a Broadway theater have not been announced. Scotty Takes a Ride Somewhere, James Doohan may be beaming. Mr. Doohan, who portrayed Scotty, the chief engineer of the starship Enterprise on ''Star Trek,'' was rocketed to the edge of space on Saturday from a desert launching ground near Truth or Consequences, N.M., Reuters reported. As hundreds of spectators applauded, cheered and wept, a capsule like those above containing the cremated ashes of Mr. Doohan, who was 85 when he died two years ago, zoomed aloft with the remains of 200 other people, including the astronaut Gordon Cooper, who went into space twice in the 1960s and died at 77 in 2004. Reaching a height of 384,000 feet, or more than 72 miles, the flight on Saturday was arranged by the Houston-based company Space Services Inc., which charges $495 to send a portion of a person's ashes on a 15-minute flight before the cargo parachutes back to Earth. The capsules are retrieved, mounted on plaques and given to relatives. ''It was great, it was fun, and we want to go again,'' said Mr. Doohan's widow, Wende Doohan, who pressed the launch button with Mr. Cooper's widow, Suzan Cooper. (P.S. Nobody on ''Star Trek'' ever actually said, ''Beam me up, Scotty.'') 'Idol' Finalist Arrested Jessica Sierra, one of the Top 10 finalists on ''American Idol'' in 2005, was arrested early yesterday in Tampa, Fla., on a felony battery charge, The Associated Press reported. She was accused of hitting a man on the head with a heavy glass at a cafe, the police said. Ms. Sierra, 21, above, was booked on a charge of aggravated battery with a deadly weapon and also charged with possession of cocaine and introduction of contraband into a correctional facility. A police spokeswoman said officers found a small amount of the drug while searching her. Bail was set at $11,500. Vonnegut's Final Bow Kurt Vonnegut's final writing -- a 13-page speech he planned to deliver at Butler University -- was a highlight of a celebration of his life and literature on Friday in his hometown, Indianapolis, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Vonnegut, the author of novels including ''Slaughterhouse-Five'' and ''Cat's Cradle,'' died on April 11 at 84. The lecture was delivered by his son, Mark, as part of a yearlong tribute to the author by Indianapolis. Mark Vonnegut said of his father, ''He was really, really serious about being funny.'' Hopping from topic to topic in the written speech, Mr. Vonnegut noted that he achieved the same military rank as Napoleon and Hitler, that he intended to sue a cigarette manufacturer for breach of promise (''Their product did not kill me'') and that the final words of a condemned man ought to be, ''This will certainly teach me a lesson.'' The last sentence of the speech was, ''I thank you for your attention, and I'm outta here.'' Footnote Alison Stewart and Luke Burbank will be the hosts of the NPR morning news show that is to make its debut in September. Their daily two-hour morning drive-time newsmagazine will be the centerpiece of a new 24-hour service intended for adults 25 to 44. Ms. Stewart will join NPR from NBC and MSNBC. Mr. Burbank has been a reporter for NPR News for four years.
